sen.j: 千早（ちはや・襅）とは、日本において古来より神事の際に用いられた衣装で、主に女性が着た。
sen.e: The chihaya has existed in Japan since ancient times and is a piece of clothing used when performing religious rituals and duties that is principally worn by women.

The chihaya (outer vestment garment) has existed in Japan since ancient times and is a piece of clothing used when performing religious rituals and duties that is principally worn by women.
sen.cmt: 説明補足しました、(outer vestment garment)

sen.j: 元は装束の上より、白無地の絹一幅の中央部分のみを縦に切れ込みを入れて頭部を通すという一種の貫頭衣のようなものだったとされている。
sen.e: Originally worn on the outside of costumes, the chihaya is simply made of solely of plain white cloth one bolt length wide with a cut made purposely in the middle for the wearer to put their head through.

sen.j: 神事の際に着用する衣装の袖や袂を上に打ちかけた千早の中にたくし込むことだった。
sen.e: The chihaya was worn over the sleeves of clothes worn when performing religious rituals and duties which were rolled up into the chihaya.

sen.j: 動作をし易くするために着用したとも言われている。
sen.e: It is said the chihaya was worn to make movement easier.

sen.j: 後に大嘗祭や新嘗祭において神饌などを供する釆女・女官の衣装となった。
sen.e: Later on, at the Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) and Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities), offerings of food and drink to the gods the chihaya was worn by uneme (court waitress of ancient Japan) and court ladies.

sen.j: 脇を縫わずに前において紐で合わせるようにして着衣する袖のない短服へと変化した。
sen.e: The armpit of the garment was not stitched closed and the garment was worn tied at the front with a cord thus having evolved into a short piece of clothing with no sleeves.

sen.j: 近世以後には無地の白絹に、青摺（あおずり）と呼ばれる、山藍を用いて草花や流水を描いたものが主となる。
sen.e: In more recent times, instead of plain white cloth, aozuri (cloth dyed deep blue) made using indigo to paint flowers, plants and streams is primarily used.

sen.j: 現在では巫女が公式の神事において通常の巫女装束 （白装束・緋袴）上に着る本式の装束として水干とともに用いられている。
sen.e: Currently, the chihaya is worn over the usual vestment (white top costume and hinohakama (scarlet hakama (divided trouser-like skirt)) worn by shrine maidens when performing formal religious rituals and duties and, is the formal piece of clothing worn with the suika (everyday garment worn by boys in ancient times).
